title: Z Axis stop for Flashforge Creator and Replicator 2

description.text:
This is a simple z axis stop which you place on the edge below the Z Stop switch.  
So if you plan on adding glass or other material to the top of your platform, this will offset it from hitting the platform.  
I have included 6, 7, and 8 mm which print in about 10 mins on the flashforge creator with .27 and 10% infil on 40/55

author: lucassaldanhawerneck

description.text:
Christmas Tree Water Boy is a pump enabled water storage system that keeps a tree stand filled and alerts you by text message when water needs to be added. No longer will you have to crawl on the floor and insert your finger in the stand of a dry tree--followed by dripping water on the gifts and floor. Every year, 25-30 million live Christmas trees are sold in the U.S., thus the potential market for an automated watering system is significant.

Christmas Tree Water Boy’s tank (disguised as a package) holds enough water for many days and it can be placed in an easy to refill location under the tree. A pump moves water from the tank into the Christmas tree stand (stand of your choice) as needed.

More instructions on assembly can be found at:
https://makershare.com/projects/christmas-tree-water-boy

I designed this dial for a friend to use as a replacement for the turn indicator that comes with the Runewars miniatures game. It is numbered from 1 through 8. No supports are needed. Just print the top half and the bottom half and slide them together. I started the design in Tinkercad and then moved over to Blender to finish it. I investigated and taught myself how to convert a bitmap, 2-dimensional image into a 3-dimensional mesh in Blender. I used some 2D art that my friend sent me to create the decoration on the top of the dial.

Cheap 15$ mod to expand the z build area of a printrbot from 150mm to 250mm or even higher if you're willing to lengthen the extruder cords.

Go to your average hardware store and purchase 2 3ft 5/16in(8mm)threaded rods and smooth rods for around 10-15$ . Replace the supplied 1ft rods with the longer ones. Optionally lengthen the wires or purchase extensions. Simple, cheap and easy way to add another 6in to your build capability. Be able to print an arm and a leg without paying for one!
HUZZAH ENJOY!

comments.text: I bought some new rods, forgot about having to lengthen the wires! D'oh! lol
comments.author: allanonmage

comments.text: Works, first I used steel rods and PLA sliders, now replaced them with 50cm smooth rods and use the lm8uu again. Wobble gets stronger the higher you print, but doesn't matter that much with big prints. 30cm tall Pink Panther Woman looks great!
comments.author: Datenkrieger

comments.text: Awesome man, be sure to let me know how those stability upgrades go, printing helmets would be awesome, that's big goal.
comments.author: Datenkrieger

comments.text:
Any updates on this? What is the tallest you have printed now?Â 
I'm on the verge of doing an upgrade like this and looking at getting metric threaded rods- just trying to figure out the best source...
comments.author: fredini

comments.text: Another Question-
comments.author: fredini

comments.text: Those rods don't look like smooth rod.  They look like steel rod.  Smooth rod is hardened steel and machined to be precise.  Its also hard to find.  If it works, it works, but I'd be interested in the longevity and accuracy of your printer.  It probably won't matter on the z axis as much as it would on the X or Y axis.
comments.author: SometimesCake

comments.text: Hey sorry for taking a while to reply. It's been about a month printing with the new rods and I was worried about rust as you said. So far though they've really not rusted in the slightest, I think the generous amount of PTFE lubricant provides some protection.The resolution is at least better than my previous rods and I've really had no problems with Z-accuracy in my prints. If I run in to troubles later on I'll post about it.
comments.author: SometimesCake

comments.text: Very Cool.
comments.author: fredini

comments.text: Note that if you use M8 threaded rods instead of 5/16in rods you have to recalibrate the Z-axis and use other nuts because the thread pitch is different.
comments.author: neredera

comments.text: Nice! How tall have you printed with that?
comments.author: fredini

comments.text: My tallest print so far has been ~250mm but at that height the cables to the extruder stepper, x bar endstop and my 40mm cooling fan all become tight so I'm working on adding length to the cables.
comments.author: fredini

title: Amiga Mean Well PSU Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simple bracket to mount a Mean Well PT-45B or PT-65B power supply into an original Amiga PSU case.

The mounting bracket is the same size as the original PCB so should be a simple replacement. No need to use any glue, or cut any plastics.

Requires 4x M3.5 screws to fix the Mean Well PSU to the bracket.

Note: The standard A500/600/1200 power supplies I have measured all have the same size board and mounting holes so this should be good for all models. Obviously it will not fit in the slim A600 PSU or any other non standard case without modification.

This is an adapter to fit common terminals to the speaker Sonab OA-12 (might fit other Sonab speakers as well). The original doesn't use terminals but use a clamp that fixes the cable with DIN-contacts in-place.

For this model, try to print it on the bigger side, because the fins can become very thin. I printed mine at about a 1" height, and the fins are in tact, but with a little pressure they are susceptible to breaking!

description.text: Following in the footsteps of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6774 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5584 , this is a ball bearing I worked on for my fillament spool, but it should be pretty flexible to use for other things too.

I tried to make the scad file pretty easy to configure.  All the configurable items are at the top in sections.
Everything is in mm.
The size parameters are fairly self explanatory, but I should point out that a minimum outside diameter is calculated and if it is larger than the one you set yours will be ignored.
Probably the most important size parameter is ball_spacing_ratio which gives the thing enough room to spin freely.  I tried a few and found that 1 is too tight, 1.2 is too loose, and 1.16 is just about right for my printer.
The shape parameters have comments to describe them, but it can do quite a few things.  Experiment to find it out!
The bearing.stl file has a 19mm opening and a 39mm outer diameter with a 4mm flange and a ball fill hole.  It takes 6mm airsoft bbs as balls.  Also, a 1/4-20 setscrew pretty much plugs the fill hole perfectly.

comments.text: I used steel BBS and it worked great. Bravo!

print_settings.Notes:: Print with fan plate facing down and arm getting vertical supports. (Same as shown in the Cura screenshot.)

description.text: A remix of a Mod for easily accessing the extruder gear. The version of that that bartoaster created works well though has a thin bridge between the extruder carriage and the fan itself, creating a huge potential for breaking. I fixed this by adding a lot more plastic, making it much more rigid. This mod is compatible with cut heatsinks and is recommended to be used with a cut heatsink.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print with fan plate facing down and arm getting vertical supports. (Same as shown in the Cura screenshot.)

Post-Printing

Remove the support material holding the hinge arm and inside the screw hole. Get a long M4 screw (not sure how long mine is, whatever screw you use in your existing fan hinge configuration should work). Remove the top left screw holding onto the top left linear bearing and install the mod there. Optionally, remove the screw under the top left-most screw for a smoother hinge.

Design

I simply took bartoaster's awesome Anet A8 fan hinge and beefed it up in 123D Design. I then cleaned it up in Blender.

author: MMDeveloper

description.text:
No two filaments are alike and no two give their best at the same temp so I made this temperature tower to test filament temperatures, it goes down to 160 as I have had some cheap chinese filaments run like water at 190 and print at 160.
I am including 3 towers a 240-160, 220-180, and 200-160 versions.

This temperature tower has square edges, lettering, 40 degree angle, 60 degree angle, and bridges

Print at 0.2mm layer height for the temperature/layer settings in the notes to apply.

I print it (stop it if it quits early) then give it a good look and see at what temperature all the above printed the best at, then I start snapping off pieces with my hands to see what temp gives me the best layer adhesion and then mark the spool with that temperature.

I use simplify3d, if you use S3D click "edit process settings" find the appropriate temperature range in the notes below and enter the "layer temperature settings" that are below into it, I "Save as new" next to "Select profile" and gave it the temperature range name so I don't have to do it again, that's it, it is really that easy with S3d.
With Cura and Slic3r you will have to manually edit the file or find a script to change the layers, cura used to have a plugin for "change at layer height" but it is not there in new versions that I can see.

If using Simplify3d set the Unsupported area threshold under the other tab to 25 or below instead of 50, 50 is a bit high for short bridges.

Printer:

any

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20-30

comments.text: FYI: The TweakAtZ plugin to change temperature at specific heights/layers was added to the Cura default install a while ago (I think in 2.3). It is still there in Cura 2.7.0, which I am using on CentOS. Don't know if it is still available in Cura 3.

print_settings.Resolution:: 0.2 for main body, 0.15 for everything else
print_settings.Notes:: In order to keep the honeycomb design on half of the original faceplate/lid, I made the 'honeycomb modifier' STL. Load up the main body in Slic3r PE and give it a 100% infill. Then, double click on the body to bring up the modifier screen, click 'load modifier' and upload the honeycomb modifier .stl. It should pop up right where it should be. Next, click on the honeycomb modifier and under part settings add these commands: Fill pattern- honeycomb, fill density- 30% (or whatever you want), bottom solid layers- 2, top solid layers- 2. If you don't have translucent filament and would still like to see the honeycomb, you can try 0 top layers to expose the infill.

title: Triforce Faceplate/Lid for Intel NUC6i7KYK Skull Canyon Computer

description.text:
Available on Etsy!

This is a triforce themed lid/faceplate for the Intel NUC 6i7KYK Skull Canyon Computer. I really like this slim computer but skulls aren't really my style. Fortunately, Intel released a template .STEP file for a lid/faceplate, in case people wanted to design their own.

I'd say this is an 'intermediate' level project, since it requires multiple filaments, nozzles, probably some post-printing sanding, and optional modifiers to be tinkered with in the slicer. However I'm pretty satisfied with the final product!

To print all the things, you will need to print:

1x NUC main body, 0.4mm nozzle, primary color
1x NUC Triforce inner, 0.25mm nozzle, primary color
1x NUC Triforce outer, 0.25mm nozzle, secondary color
3x NUC Inner Circle Large, 0.25mm nozzle, secondary color
6x NUC Inner Circle Medium, 0.25mm nozzle, secondary color
6x NUC Inner Circle Small, 0.25mm nozzle, secondary color
3x NUC Outer Circle Large, 0.25mm nozzle, secondary color
3x NUC Outer Circle Medium, 0.25mm nozzle, secondary color
1x NUC Sigil, 0.25mm nozzle, secondary color
[OPTIONAL] 1x honeycomb modifier, this is just for the slicer, not to be printed

The main body needs supports, unfortunately.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 for main body, 0.15 for everything else

Infill:

Variable

Notes:

Sliced using Slic3r Prusa Edition.

My primary color was MakerGeeks Crystal Series PETG translucent blue filament, because I wanted to see the honeycomb infill on the modifier, and I eventually want to put some LEDS inside around the sigil. Nozzle at 255, bed at 90, extrusion multiplier at 1.05, fan speed from 30-50%, retraction length 1.2 mm at 35mm/sec.

Secondary color was a carbon fiber PLA, nozzle 240, bed 58, extrusion multiplier 0.9, fan speed 85-100%.

In order to keep the honeycomb design on half of the original faceplate/lid, I made the 'honeycomb modifier' STL. Load up the main body in Slic3r PE and give it a 100% infill. Then, double click on the body to bring up the modifier screen, click 'load modifier' and upload the honeycomb modifier .stl. It should pop up right where it should be. Next, click on the honeycomb modifier and under part settings add these commands: Fill pattern- honeycomb, fill density- 30% (or whatever you want), bottom solid layers- 2, top solid layers- 2. If you don't have translucent filament and would still like to see the honeycomb, you can try 0 top layers to expose the infill.

Mounting the secondary pieces into the main body

This takes a little work and since the pieces are so small you may need to adjust settings or do some sanding. Once they are place how you want, I used some hot glue from the underside to keep them in place.

Sanding

Once the secondary pieces are mounted, I sanded the whole project from 220 to 400 to 1000 to 2000 grit wet sandpaper. Smoothed out everything a whole lot!

remixed_from.title: Bed corner for mounting a 3/16 Aluminum Build Plate

title: Silicone tube based corner mounts for Lulzbot Taz 1-5 and Aluminum bed plates

description.text:
This project allows you to use silicone rubber fuel tubing in place of your springs. The tube I am using was intended for a chain saw, and is about 1/4" in diameter. You need 4 identically cut tube lengths about the same length as the stock springs, several M3 heat set inserts, and the stock M3 mounting hardware and bed retention fingers. You may need slightly longer M3 bolts depending on the final length of your tubing.

Instructions. Print from ABS (PLA will melt here) then remove the integrated support inner tube from the bottom of the mount. Insert the silicon tube up into the mount, then attach to the bed as usual. When tightening the silicon tube, it will tend to expand in diameter. I've had the corners all the way down to the aluminum without splitting the mount, but depending on your tube density, you may want to check the gap when installing. The mounts have the tube up inside them, so are theoretically slightly shorter bed profile overall so you may need to adjust your nozzle closer to the bed.

Note: This corner is dimensionally sized to work with a 12" x 12" x 3/16" aluminum plate. It will be slightly loose on a stock 300mm x 300mm Glass bed. You can compensate with spacers if you like.

author: thirty7

title: Stacked TripleFeed ("pagoda") Patch Array for FPV

description.text:
Following the release of the famous open-source "Pagoda" antenna by Maarten Baert in 2016, a circularly-polarized omni antenna for 5.8g FPV which truly challenged the "Clover leaf" antenna specs-wise as the dominator of drone video transmitter's antenna, Maarten and Robin Theunis came up with the 5.8g circularly-polarized directional antenna called the 5.8g Triple-feed Patch in 2017, which challenged the very popular "Cross-hair" antenna's place as the best video receiver's antenna. Here, I present to you a stacked array of two Triple-feed Patches which offers a bigger horizontal beam-width and higher gain than a single Triple-feed patch. Attached is the STL file for the bezel to hold the two patches in a vertical array arrangement which is essential for wide horizontal beam. Also provided here, is the step-by-step video tutorial to phase two Triple-feed patches accurately to achieve similar results like an expensive Mini-Circuits 5.8g 2way splitter.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pkux2bY1Lkc

author: RCConcepts

title: Handred80
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Handred80 fue parte de un proyecto de la Universidad Nacional de Asunción desarrollado por Mariela Benítez. Consiste en una prótesis para adultos con desarticulación de muñeca que aprovecha la rotación de antebrazo (supinación y pronación), con el objetivo de facilitar el uso de la prótesis de mano.

El principio de funcionamiento es el mismo que las prótesis para amputación transradial, las cuales se accionan con la flexión del codo. La Flexy Hand de Steve Wood fue modificada para este dispositivo.

Esta prótesis varía considerablemente en la zona de muñeca (base de la palma y socket) de una persona a otra, se debe modificar a medida. comunícate con PO Paraguay a [email protected]

Videos:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7bSSij4WSrw
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FAjDCL5ImOk
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HLlgR2qdhYE

Desarrollado por: Mariela Benítez. Contacto: [email protected]

Etapas:

Mano
  • Ensamblar R_hand (la palma) con los R_fingerplate (dedos) y los Flex_Finger.
  • Colocar los hilos a los dedos R_fingerplate pasando por la palma R_hand.
Antebrazo
  • Termoformar el R_Socket utilizando la base de palma R_hand como guía, ambas piezas poseen encastres
  • Pegar el Candado a los encastres del R_Socket
  • Pasar los hilos por el R_Socket
  • Termoformar R_forearm y R_tríceps según dimensión del usuario
  • Unir R_forearm termoformada y R_triceps usando los Flex_ring_elbow y los Pins.
  • Conectar el R_Socket y R_Forearm con un tubo de 4mm de diámetro externo
Mecanismo de funcionamiento
  • Pasar los hilos por el Tubo y las piezas de R_Forearm-triceps hasta los Tensioners.
  • Ajustar los hilos con los Tensioners. Utilizar el orificio para el pulgar y el tensioner para los otros dedos.

Máquinas utilizadas:

FlashForge Creator Dual o FlashForge Dreamer.

Material utilizado

Estas permiten imprimir PLA y filamento flexible.

Caractiristicas

Se imprime con 0.2 mm de altura de capa y con 80% de relleno (tipo rejilla), con ángulos de 90 y 0. Con una velocidad de impresión de 60 mm/s (dependiendo de la impresora).
Se aplica a:

  • R_Forearm,
  • R_socket,
  • R_Triceps,
  • Candado,
  • Tensioners,
  • Pins

Se imprime con 0.2 mm de altura de capa y con 20% de relleno (tipo rejilla), con ángulos de 90 y 0. Con una velocidad de impresión de 60 mm/s (dependiendo de la impresora).
Se aplica a:

  • R_hand,
  • R_fingerplate

Se imprime con 0.2 mm de altura de capa y con 20% de relleno (tipo rejilla), con ángulos de 90 y 0. Con una velocidad de impresión de 15 mm/s. (Esta velocidad depende del tipo de flexible y el tipo de impresora usada)
Se aplica a:
Se aplica a:

  • Flex_Finger,
  • Flex_ring_elbow

Handred80 was part of a project of the National University of Asunción (Paraguay) developed by the Industrial Designer Mariela Benítez. It is a prosthetic hand for adults with wrist disarticulation that takes advantage of the forearm’s rotation (supination and pronation).

The operating principle is the same as prostheses for transradial amputation, which are activated by elbow flexion. Steve Wood's Flexy Hand was modified for this device.

This prosthesis varies considerably in the wrist area from one person to another and it must be modified to measure (base of the palm and socket). Contact PO Paraguay at [email protected]

Developed by: Mariela Benítez. Contact: [email protected]

Assembly Guide

Hand

  • Assemble R_hand (the palm) with the R_fingerplate (fingers) and the Flex_Finger.
  • Place the threads to the fingers R_fingerplate passing through the palm R_hand.

Forearm

  • Thermoform the R_Socket using the palm base R_hand as a guide. Both pieces have inserts
  • Stick the padlock to the R_Socket inserts
  • Pass the threads through the R_Socket
  • Termoform R_forearm and R_tríceps according to user dimension
  • Join thermoformed R_forearm and R_triceps using the Flex_ring_elbow and Pins.
  • Connect the R_Socket and R_Forearm with a 4mm outer diameter tube

Operating mechanism

  • Pass the threads through the Tube and the pieces of R_Forearm-triceps to the Tensioners.
  • Adjust the threads with the Tensioners. Use the hole for the thumb and the tensioner for the other fingers.
Print settings

Printers used:
FlashForge Creator Dual or FlashForge Dreamer.

Used material:
Printed with PLA and flexible filament.

Characteristics:

  1. Printed with 0.2 mm layer height and with 80% filling (grid type), with angles of 90 and 0. With a printing speed of 60 mm / s (depending on the printer).
    It applies to:
    R_Forearm,
    R_socket,
    R_Triceps,
    Padlock,
    Tensioners,
    Pins

  2. Printed with 0.2 mm layer height and with 20% fill (grid type), with angles of 90 and 0. With a print speed of 60 mm / s (depending on the printer).
    It applies to:
    R_hand,
    R_fingerplate

  3. Printed with 0.2 mm layer height and 20% fill (grid type), with angles of 90 and 0. With a print speed of 15 mm / s. (This speed depends on the type of flexible and the type of printer used)
    It applies to:
    Flex_Finger,
    Flex_ring_elbow

description.text:
Edit: I made one finally, and the fit between top and bottom required a bit of help from a hammer, but it fit fine. I also revised the interior support for the base as I previously couldn't fit the BB's in it, but you can now.

I needed a stand to rest the vac line against in the hood, so I designed this 2 part stand. The base is a shell with a center support in the bottom ring to support printing. I left the base hollow so that BB's or sand could be added to give the stand some weight. Once filled, the top should snap into the base, though removing it later will be tricky/impossible. This is still a work in progress, so any suggestions are welcome.

shouldn't need supports if you orient the parts on the print bed correctly. I will be printing this on the MP select mini V2, I have to scale both parts down to 97% to get it to fit the print bed.

title: A8 Fan Shroud for Quick Filament Changes

description.text:
Changing filament on the A8 is tricky b/c you can't see the filament feed path. 75% of the time, I couldn't get it to work, and found it was "easier" to unscrew the whole extruder mechanism, which is preloaded by the spring and etc. -- a pain in the rump.

There are a few good solutions out there. Mine's a minimalistic combination of two of them.

In particular, I took the cut-down-the-heatsink approach and inspiration for the half-shroud from [nicolaidiz] https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2037833 but I didn't want all of the extraneous hinging just to hold a fan loosely in place.

Where my design has an ad-hoc clip, [85holmberg] has a nice basket to sit the fan in (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2326111) and that looks a lot more pro. The pillars that support the basket block airflow from the sides of the heatsink, however, and I could figure out a way to design around it.

Anyway, the clip has worked for me for around 100 printing hours, so I'm calling it good until I get bored / inspired. :)

The Heatsink: I cut the heatsink with a hacksaw after the fourth rib. [85holmberg] has good instructions. I also drilled two holes in the top rib that allow air to leave the fan vents and pass through the heatsink fins. (See the third photo.) I do this because my shroud sits directly on the top fin, and most of the flow from the fan would otherwise be blocked.

The cold side of the heatbreak seems to stay cold enough with the fan running and this minimal amount of heatsink in place. YMMV.

I'd still like to see a better, quieter, or more elegant solution, but this works so well that I'm not messing with it further. If you get inspired, let me know!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.25, not critical at all.

Infill:

Whatevs.

Notes:

The shroud is basic and blocky, should print as-is without support with easy bridging. The clip will end up solid in most slicers.

None of this is critical. Easy peasy. Fo sheezy.

title: Presto Pegasus Symmetry R5 part: Improved Battery Mount

description.text:
This is a improved battery mount for Presto Pegasus's Symmetry R5 frame.

Compared to the previous version of battery mount, this new design is improved by:

  • Increasing the overall thickness of the battery mount to improve durability
  • Increasing the overall volume/size of the strap holding area to improve durability
  • Fully compatible with ABS filament

Normally, Carbon reinforced ABS is used to print this part but TPU is also recommended if you don't want brittle characteristics.

Recommended infill setting is 70% but anywhere between 40%~100% will be OK, depends on your preference (weight vs durability of the part)

This file is free to use except for commercial use.

title: Power Wheels Wild Thing Control Plate

description.text: We are switch adapting a power wheels wild thing for use in our clinic and for loans to kids who would benefit from access to early mobility. The stock controller uses hall effects sensors on the levers and requires two hands to operate. This new controller (Arduino and Sabertooth) can limit the speed, reduce the torque jerking, and provides options for switch control input that were not available in the stock controller.
Fusion 360's sheet metal workspace was used to design this part.

title: Laser cut Mendel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is our first public release for a laser cut design for the Mendel.
All parts are redesigned so they can be lasercutted.
This design is made from a sheet of acryl with a thickness of 4mm. This design is the result of a master thesis at the University College of Ghent(Belgium) by me, Frederic Decru.
My promoter is Peter Van Ransbeeck, my co promotor is Kurt Van Houtte and my coaches Mathias Vermeulen and Batist Leman. Triggered by the lecture by dr. Adrian Bowyer at our University, and by the design challenge by Bre Pettis @ Makerbot I\\\\'m glad to submit this thesis to the public domain by posting it on Thingiverse. Caution: This version is under development and so a lot of improvements can be made, feel free to post derivatives! http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5CjsulmxUBw Coreldraw filles online
The manual and partlist are online

If you find yourself having trouble with the solve, a solution video is at https://youtu.be/AQlhz7089M0. A containment box for the puzzle is at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2697130.

NOTE: YOU WILL NEED TWO COPIES OF "PIECE 7"

Would it be important to mention that I'm the only one I know who has solved it? Comment if you solved it without looking at the solution.

EDIT #1: Somebody pointed out in the comment section that the tolerances were a bit too tight to be printed properly. This was my mistake and I apologize for any wasted filament.
My recommendation would be to use a file or sandpaper to bring faces to more reasonable tolerances. I will be updating the model as soon as I have the time to repair all the individual pieces.

EDIT #2: OK, I added some spacing between the pieces of the puzzle. There should be ~1mm between pieces. Again, sorry for any wasted filament.

Now I will print a box and then give it as a puzzle to our PhD students who love these challenges!
Many thanks!

title: How to calibrate laser Z height

description.text:
How to calibrate laser Z height

  1. send laser head to home by G28 instruction, put A4 sheet on table
  2. turn laser ON (in my case M42 P44 S255)
  3. send laser head to X=180, Y=180, Z=45mm (in my case maximum Z height=45 mm), may be you need to increase or decrease moving speed
  4. turn laser OFF (may be here you should go to Z=0 height to make second burn point
  5. measure distance between begin and end of burned line
  6. calculate optimum Z height as described on the picture

title: Chain guard for road bike Tiagra 52 theet chainring
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I use my road bike to get to university and work and therefore I'm not a big fan of black stripes on my trousers.

I couldn't find a commercially chain guard for the Tiagra crank I'm driving and couldn't find a printable one that would fit on my bike. I also didn't liked to use screws to put it on my bike.

So I designed this chain guard. It has Inbus pins which are getting thicker towards the base to be able to push them tightly into the chain ring bolts. You will have to turn the bolts slightly to align them with the pins which needs a little bit of trying, but when you have them right the guard easily pushes in. A few (light) whacks with a hammer helps to secure the guard in place.
The cutout around the crank was needed to fit the print on my printbed. Minimum size needed to print this in one piece is 220x220mm.

I printed it in PLA and have used it for around half a year almost daily and had no issues with it. It doesn't come loose and protects the trousers very nicely. Only thing it can't protect you from is your trousers touching the chain behind the chain ring (Happens only with very wide trousers).

description.text: Update:Faire Play III has launched! See the latest and greatest in Barbie-compatible 3D printed wargear over at Zheng3.com. Spoiler: It's a fully articulated battle tardigrade. We now return you to your regular model description.

Sing, O muse, of science and of art and of trials and tessellation and tribulations, of dawn-laboring Zheng, and Barbie of the slim ankles.
Acolytes rush to Delphi's shimmering pool to behold the emerging vision. Great Hera! A Kickstarter begins!
UPDATE Faire Play was a sucess! The Kickstarter was overfunded and the Parade Armor is finished and on sale to the rest of the world.

With Faire Play, I'm making 3D printed medieval armor for Barbie dolls. To the goddess of Wisdom I offer this Athena Makeover Kit as tribute, so that She may guide this campaign to success.
Watch Barbie's debut in full battle gear in the Kickstarter video, and support Open Source design while you're there.

The spear and aegis should clip on to pretty much any doll that's roughly Barbie-sized, but the boots are designed specifically for a doll in the Barbie Fashionistas line.
I've got the prototype medieval armor finished and reliably printing on an FDM printer, now I just need to make it look fabulous. I'll be posting updates at faireplay.zheng3.com over the next couple of weeks. #staytuned!

description.text:
You're looking for a nice gift? For Christmas, birthday, Valentine's day, or just yourself?
You've found it: The Litho.BOX!

Litho.BOX is a compact stand for your lithophane with LED backlight. The frame is wide enough to spread the light evenly. Note: 5.8mm of the lithophane will be covered at every side so you can set a border in the lithophane accordingly (but you don't have to :). The sizes in the names correlate to the lithophane's dimensions (e.g. 10x10 will fit a 10 by 10cm lithophane).

All you need is

  • a Lithophane (e.g. from http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/)
  • a power jack socket (e.g. from https://www.banggood.com/50pcs-DC-005-3Pin-Black-DC-Power-Jack-Socket-Connector-5_52_1mm-p-1127042.html)
  • a 12V power supply (e.g. from https://www.banggood.com/DC-12V-1A-AC-100-240V-Adapter-Power-Supply-EU-Plug-For-LED-Strip-p-948163.html)
  • a 12V LED strip (e.g. from https://www.banggood.com/5M-White-3528-SMD-LED-Strip-Light-Non-Waterproof-12V-DC-300-LED-p-77079.html)
  • and of course the Litho.BOX base and lid

The Litho.BOX features a little support for the power jack socket, but can also be used without it. Litho.BOX also is suited for 8mm and 10mm wide LED strips.
If you need differently sized boxes just let me know in the comments! The model is not customizable as I modeled it in Fusion 360.

I made a bust of Hatty Hattington (Hatty Hattington is a character from BattleBlock Theater.).

Here are some decorated disks for a two color printer. The disks print in a few minutes and the openSCAD program provided can be modified to quickly try out ideas for two color prints. The patterns extend completely through the disks which are only 2.5 mm thick. The disks might serve as refrigerator magnets, math teaching tools, earings, or mobiles. Twelve of the images are derived from plane curves. They are: cardioid
catenary
evolute of ellipse
sine
three-leaved rose
strophoid
witch of agnesi
lemniscate of bernoulli
limacon
parabola
cubical parabola
semicubical parabola You will find much information about all of these curves on the internet. Pairs of stl files for 3 of the disks are included below: disk_less_evolute.stl and evolute.stl
disk_less_witch.stl and witch.stl
disk_less_sine.stl and sine.stl Decorated_disks_stl.zip contains all 14 pairs of stl files.

The disks are 40 mm in diameter and 2.5 mm thick and have a 1 mm raised rim on the upper side.  Printed directly on the build platform they have attractive surfaces.
The openSCAD code allows one to vary the size and thickness of the disks and the decorations.  The rim can be eliminated to produce a simple disk if that is required.
A single open scad program produced all of the disks.  A decoration is chosen from a list and the other members are commented out.  The program is run once using the difference statement to make say disk_less_evolute.stl.  The program is then run a second time using the intersection statement to produce evolute.stl.

description.text: low poly fox

This is a model of a tetrahemihexahedron, the only non-convex uniform polyhedron with seven faces. What makes this polyhedron different from the ones we're used to seeing, where the faces only touch along their edges, is that three of the faces pass through each other. The seven faces are the four equilateral triangles and three large squares that intersect in the center. The smaller right triangles that can be seen on the model are actually sections (one quarter each) of the squares; they don't end at the center, but pass through to the other side. This is analogous to the way a Klein surface (another non-orientable object) must pass through itself in order to be represented in three dimensions. It's easier to see with a model that has each square a different color, as in this video. To make a printable version of the tetrahemihexahedron, we have to resort to an approximation. Neither OpenSCAD nor the 3D printer can handle a model with intersecting but continuous faces, so this model has small fillets along those intersections to make it manifold and printable. The fillets are small enough that they don't show up in the finished print.

Choose whether you would like to print the model with a solid face or a hollow face on the printbed; there are STLs for both, and you can also make the choice in Customizer. Both versions work fine on our printers, but one may work better than the other for you; when printing with the hollow face down I added a brim to make sure it stuck to the bed. Customizer can also be used to change the size of the print; the STLs are 50 mm along each edge.

This a very sturdy spool holder with easy to adjust size. It uses 608z bearing such as those found in skateboards and inline roller blades. The rods that support the filament are 8mm linear bearing rods normally found in 3d printers. The linear rods support the filament and also give the roller structural support. You should be all set with two linear rods going through the 608z bearing. But in the event that you want more support you can use the couple of holes right next to the cavities that hold the bearings.

You are welcome to copy the fusion 3d file and use for whatever you want. Any derived work would be nice if it included attributions. http://a360.co/2k82uMM

description.text:
"Kill the A.N.T.s" desktop sign.

Dr. Daniel Amen, is a physician, psychiatrist, and is considered to be one of the world's leading experts on brain health and mental health, has an expression he likes to tell his patients:

"Kill the A.N.T.s"

ANT Therapy

A.N.T.s stands for: "Automatic Negative Thoughts"
My Clif Notes:

  • Your brain gets "infested" with these negative thoughts.
  • Any thoughts you have affect your body as well as your mind so they are a big deal.
  • If you think about bad things you will feel worse.
  • If you think about good things you will feel better.
  • Your automatic thoughts are not always truthful. Don't believe them without question!
  • Ask yourself: "Is this true?"
  • And: "Will thinking this make anything better?"

If not, squash the ANTs!

I wanted to be reminded of this during the day so I designed and printed out this sign!

Notes:
STL File:
  • The STL File is already oriented the way it needs to be printed.
  • You can see in the photo the last period after the "T" isn't correct. I fixed the model before loading the STL up on Thingiverse.
  • I provide a notch in the model where it comes in contact with the print bed so that you can use something like a screw driver to help pry the print off when its done.
Slicer
  • Slicer Used: Simplify 3D
  • Number of Top/Bottom Layers: 3
  • I figured out which layers that I wanted to the printer to pause at so I could swap out the different colored filaments.

  • In my S3D Factory file I:

    • Clicked on the "Edit Process Settings" button.
    • Clicked on the "Scripts" tab.
    • There will be a bottom panel labeled: "Post Processing"
    • There is a text box labeled: "Additional terminal commands for post processing"
    • Fill in like this:

    {REPLACE "; layer" "M117 Layer"}
    {REPLACE " Z = " " Z="}
    {REPLACE "\nM117 Layer 77, Z=" "\nG1 X10 Y5\nM0\nM117 Layer 77, Z="}
    {REPLACE "\nM117 Layer 109, Z=" "\nG1 X10 Y5\nM0\nM117 Layer 109, Z="}
    {REPLACE "\nM117 Layer 117, Z=" "\nG1 X10 Y5\nM0\nM117 Layer 117, Z="}
    {REPLACE "\nM117 Layer 141, Z=" "\nG1 X10 Y5\nM0\nM117 Layer 141, Z="}

    • Notice above the layer entries... These tell the printer which layers to pause on.
    • Your layer numbers may be different based on your layer height and the scale of the model.
    • If you have Simplify 3D, and are interested, I've uploaded the factory file that I used for this.
    • I believe all the other popular slicers have ways of setting up for the print to pause when reaching certain layers.
Colors used:
  • 1st section: Matterhackers White Pro Series PLA (2.85mm)
  • 2nd section: eSun Black PLA+ (2.85mm)
  • 3rd section: eSun Red PLA+ (2.85mm)
  • 4th section: Polymaker PolyLite PLA Translucent Blue (2.85mm)
  • 5th section: eSun Pine Green PLA+ (2.85mm)

title: Sakura D4 Customizable Rear Suspension Mount

description.text:
I decided to change the toe in of my Sakura D4. I had the RR+30 mount installed which I believe means 3 degrees of toe in. Included on the kit was a part called RR+10 which, I guess, means 1 degree of toe in. Since I wanted zero toe, I designed a customizable-toe suspension mount. And since I was at it, and I really dislike the tiny shims, I made also the height customizable.

On the customizer, you enter the distance in mm (center to center) between the pins of the suspension arms. The RR+30 has about 46mm, the RR+10 has about 43mm so I extrapolated and used 42mm for zero toe. Installed, the toe seems to be zero (at least with my eyes - if you have better data, please say so. If someone can actually measure the distance on a zero toe part, it would be useful here).

Also, on the customizer you can edit the additional height in mm (imagine it as the height of the shim below the suspension mount). The kit had 0.5mm shims. Btw, here you can adjust for your printer's dimensional inaccuracy. E.g. I used 1mm and my rear camber became positive!
You can give negative values to height, thought below 2mm the pin hole sleeves get in the way.

Feel free to experiment with the values and please report here anything of importance that you discover!

On the photos you can see the zero toe part I printed (previous version, that's why it's a bit ugly) above the RR+10 and the RR+30 parts. I decided to omit the two little protrusions (which I had forgot and broke while uninstalling my RR+30). It seems to work ok without them, if someone knows why they exist please tell me.

I also include three stl files with zero toe and three different shim heights (0mm, 0.5mm, 1mm) with the toe in raised text left and right, and the shim height indented in the center - unfortunately no way for this to work on the customizer!

The zero toe part works like a charm!

title: CCG Deck Box with Geared Pivoting Lid

description.text:
This is a gloriously over-complicated box for storing cards, or anything else really. As the lid is opened the platform rises, presenting the cards. 20/03/2014
Added pre-layed-out plates! You can now select 7 plates in the Customizer to greatly reduce the number of prints, but if you have trouble printing full-bed objects, or have a smaller printer, just grab the individual STL files and print those. The filename has either 1x or 2x to indicate how many to print. I also redesigned the lid parts so that they can be printed in an orientation allowing the whole top to be the same finish. 13/03/2014
I have added the option to put any of the five MTG mana logos on any of the four main sides of the box. You can't do this from the Customizer, because it requires some external STL files, but if you download all the files, you can edit the deck_box.scad file and set the logos you want. I have also added some options for generating pre-made plate layouts. Just print one of each of the "Plate" parts. These will automatically put the specified logos on each of the panels too.

12/03/2014
This is a remix I made of belrius' "CCG deck box with geared pivoting lid".
Mostly the changes are just to make this more Customizer-friendly, but I have also removed the front/back panel decoration, and removed most of the CSG problems with the resultant STL files. Still need to clean a couple of parts up that are creating odd non-manifold files.
Latest source, stl's and scripts can be found in the GitHub Repository.

There are 13 parts defined in the file that you need to print. There are also plated options to reduce that to 7 separate prints. 1x 1:Front panel
1x 2:Back Panel
1x 3:Left
1x 4:Right
2x 5:Gear rack
1x 6:Hinged lid (left)
1x 7:Hinged lid (right)
2x 8:Hinge mount
2x 9:Mechanism holder
2x 10:Top hinge
2x 11:Side hinge
1x 12:Platform
1x 13:Base Alternatively, print just ONE of each of these:
1x 14:Plate A
1x 15:Plate B
1x 16:Plate C
1x 17:Plate D
1x 18:Plate E
1x 19:Plate F
1x 20:Plate G

description.text: A wall for a 3D printed snow plow.

60/5000
Model for explaining a pneumatic valve symbol.
NGSS
Model for the operation of a pneumatic symbol With this model you can explain to students how a symbol of a valve works.
Model for the operation of a pneumatic symbol With this model you can explain to students how a symbol of a valve works.
PLA felement

The Scenario
We put in new grass and plants up front and wanted to make sure the neighbors were extra careful around the area for the first few weeks while it all settles into place.

The Thing
I worked up this simple yard/lawn stake that you can poke into the ground for all to see and hopefully read. There is also an option back plate you can print for added contrast. Say you print the sign in white but don't think it's too visible, you can print the back part in black and then stick em together with a dab of super glue. Alternatively, you can put some dark tape back there as a background.
